title: Decompose IEth1Notifier into parts

body:
With the machinery above, the _genesis builder_ can control when to get blocks / eth1 data:

pseudocode for a stateless genesis builder:
- constructor takes eth1 provider and beacon config
  - create and manage an empty deposit tree
  - create and manage an empty genesis state
  - start from some known block number
- use getFollowDepositEventsStream to handle batched deposit events for each block
  - incrementally build genesis state and deposit tree
  - once the state has min_validators
    - begin fetching eth1 data and timestamp w/ provider.getBlock and getEth1Data
    - optionally: if fetched timestamp is before min_genesis_time, don't fetch eth1 data again 'until necessary'
  - if a valid genesis is found, abort stream
- throw error if managed state is invalid (eth1 provider stopped before genesis processed)
- return genesis state, deposit tree, last processed block number on success, if managed state is valid

Note1: This can be run entirely without the db, which is great for keeping things simple.
Depending on how fast this is, we likely don't even need to store pre-genesis deposits to db, but only store to db after a valid genesis state is returned -- outside of the scope of genesis builder.
Or we can 'save our progress' to the db by having genesis builder accept a starting deposit tree and block number, return the processed deposit tree and last processed block number in the 'error case', to be saved to db on shutdown.

Note2: Because we use the state.validators.length to compare against min_validators, we don't run into the issue of fetching eth1 data "too soon" as we do now when comparing # of deposit events against min_validators. :)
Agree on the vision for this. Meta-assigning this issue to self
